etymology_text:
/zo e/ â†’ /zoe/ â†’ /zeË/ â†’ /ze/
Shift via monophthongization of older ããˆ (zoe), in turn from sentence-ending emphatic particle ã (zo) and exclamatory or familiar particle ãˆ (e).
First dated to 1771. Usage became established in the Edo area, then spread to the Kansai region in the late 1700s.
With the softening effect of particle ãˆ (e), the sense was originally somewhat less gruff than using just ã (zo). However, in modern usage, this is now generally considered more gruff than ã (zo), and usage is restricted to informal masculine speech, either between members of the same group and status, or by a social superior to an inferior.

etymology_text:
âŸ¨noâ‚‚âŸ© â†’ */nÉ™/ â†’ /no/
From Old Japanese ã® (noâ‚‚), in turn from Proto-Japonic *nÉ™. Appears in common use in the Kojiki (712 CE). Perhaps also cognate with *nÉ™, an element found in some Old Korean place names spelled as ä¹ƒ and ä».
May be an apophonic form of Old Japanese particle ãª (na). This other form also appears in a similar function. However, its usage was already restricted to certain set expressions by the time of the earliest Japanese texts in the Nara period, with no clear examples of productive use. These appears to be adjacent to the vowels /a/, /o/, or /u/, suggesting na was an assimilated version of no.
In Old Japanese, there are three particles used productively to mark one noun modifying another:
* ã¤ (tsu), as in æ²–ã¤å³¶å®ˆ (oki tsu shimamori, â€œthe caretaker or watchman of an island of the offing [offshore]â€) or é»„æ³‰ã¤å›½ (yomo tsu kuni, â€œthe country of the underworldâ€).
* ãŒ (ga), as in é–¢ãƒ¶åŸ (Sekigahara, a placename, parseable as seki â€œcheckpoint, barrierâ€ + ga [possessive] + hara â€œfield, plainâ€)
* ã® (no), as in å€­ã®ä¸€æœ¬è–„ (Yamato no hitomoto susuki, â€œthe sawtooth sedge of Yamatoâ€, a line from one of the songs in the Kojiki)
The apophonic form ãª (na) persisted only as an element in certain compounds, such as æ¸¯ (minato, â€œharborâ€, generally parsed as mi â€œwaterâ€ + na [possessive] + to â€œdoor, gateâ€ â†’ port, landing, harbor), or æŒ (tanagokoro, â€œpalm of the handâ€, parsed as ta â€œhandâ€ + na [possessive] + kokoro â€œheart, centerâ€, changing to gokoro due to rendaku).

args.title: Etymology details
args.1: * The former kere part has multiple possible derivations: *# The å·²ç„¶å½¢ (izenkei, â€œrealis formâ€) suffix for classical -ku adjectives (modern -i adjectives) *# The å·²ç„¶å½¢ (izenkei, â€œrealis formâ€) suffix for classical negative supposition auxiliary verb ã¾ã˜ (maji) *# The å·²ç„¶å½¢ (izenkei, â€œrealis formâ€) of classical past recollective auxiliary verb ã‘ã‚Š (keri) : Auxiliary verb maji conjugates almost identically to a classical -ku adjective, so 1 and 2 above can be broadly viewed together. This theory is somewhat flawed, in that the regular realis form of classical -ku adjectives would be not -kere, but rather -kare (as the fusion of adverbial ending -ku + the realis form are of classical copular or â€œto beâ€ verb ã‚ã‚Š (ari), modern ã‚ã‚‹ (aru)). There are historical examples of -ku + are fusing into -kere, but these appear to be restricted to early modern Japanese in the Kyoto area, while keredomo appears in the late middle Japanese period and was not restricted to Kyoto. : The realis form of past recollective auxiliary verb keri was likewise formed by fusion, combining ki with the realis form are of existence verb ã‚ã‚Š (ari, â€œto beâ€). There are other documented examples of the diphthong ia changing into e, so the shift from ki + are to kere would not be unexpected. Some theories point towards the ki element being the past recollective auxiliary verb ki, but this had no known continuative form (for joining to following verbs). Other theories suggest that this was the continuative stem form ki of Old Japanese verb æ¥ (ku, â€œto comeâ€), which would fit grammatically, with the compound presumably meaning â€œhaving come to be, having come into beingâ€. Compare English be that as it may. * The latter domo part was itself originally a compound of ã© (do, conjunctive particle introducing a contrary condition) + ã‚‚ (mo, â€œeven, alsoâ€, particle). The do conjunctive particle grammatically requires that the preceding conjugation be in the realis form, and this is indeed the form used for the preceding kere portion of keredomo.

Used to mark the indirect object or patient of a causative expression. This appears very early in the written record in the Shoku Nihongi, completed in 797 CE, representing late-Nara period and early-Heian period Japanese. This usage persists in the modern language, but is restricted to formal literary writing.
